importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, when OpenAI announced new policies for Sora 2 in response to Hollywood concerns.
The date when California Governor Gavin Newsom signed a bill requiring consent for the use of actors' digital replicas.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which California's consent legislation was enacted and the subsequent push for federal action—the 'NO FAKES' Act—began, reflecting a growing industry-wide concern about AI-generated content using real people's likenesses.

keyTakeAways: OpenAI introduced Sora 2, an AI tool that generates hyperrealistic audio and video from text and images, sparking ethical and legal concerns from Hollywood studios, unions, and talent agencies.
AI-generated videos of historical figures like Martin Luther King Jr., Robin Williams, and Michael Jackson doing unauthorized actions have been widely criticized as exploitative and disrespectful.
Robin Williams' daughter Zelda publicly denounced such content as 'horrible slop,' calling it 'disgusting, over-processed hotdogs' made from real people's lives.

Hollywood talent agencies, including United Talent Agency and Creative Artists Agency, have voiced strong opposition to AI platforms using performers' likenesses without consent, credit, or compensation.
The Motion Picture Association reported that Sora 2 videos have infringed on copyrighted characters, such as SpongeBob SquarePants cooking illicit drugs.
SAG-AFTRA and talent agencies are now supporting federal legislation called the 'NO FAKES Act' to enforce consent requirements for the use of digital replicas of people.

OpenAI has responded by implementing an 'opt-in' policy allowing individuals to control how and whether their likeness is simulated, and has agreed to remove existing AI-generated content involving real people like Martin Luther King Jr.
OpenAI has blocked the public generation of well-known characters and will take down non-compliant content, with a commitment to give rightsholders greater control over their digital representations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: OpenAI's release of Sora 2, an AI tool generating hyperrealistic audio and video, has sparked significant concern from Hollywood studios, talent agencies, and unions over unauthorized use of real people's likenesses. Videos have emerged depicting historical figures like Martin Luther King Jr. and Robin Williams doing things they never did, and even real actors such as Sam Altman being used in inappropriate scenarios. These creations have been condemned as exploitative, disrespectful, and infringing on intellectual property. In response, talent agencies including United Talent Agency and Creative Artists Agency, along with SAG-AFTRA, have pushed for stronger legal protections, supporting the federal 'NO FAKES Act' to enforce consent, credit, and compensation. OpenAI has responded with an 'opt-in' policy, blocking the public generation of well-known characters and removing existing non-compliant content, including videos of Martin Luther King Jr. and SpongeBob SquarePants, showing a shift toward greater artist control in AI content creation.
title: Hollywood Pushes OpenAI for Consent
